title: On chapter 7 can you list your on schedule c or on schedule d loan payment is current balance left owing is $3,923.00?
question: filing chapter7 due to disability
answers:
In addition to the comments above, I would also remind you that ALL debts must be listed. It does not matter if the payments are current or not. If you owe a debt to anyone, the debt must be listed on D, E, or F depending on the type of debt.

Most consultations are free, you may want to consider getting legal advice before filing. If your only income is disability, you may be judgment proof. However, many find that filing the bankruptcy and discharging all dischargeable debt is much easier/cheaper/quicker than dealing with the creditors for many more years to come. Further, you can start to rebuild your credit fairly quickly after your discharge. Good lunck.

Schedule C is for exempting assets, not for debts (amounts you owe). The loan would be listed on Schedule D or F, depending on whether it's secured by property (car loan or house loan, etc) or not. You might consider retaining an experienced bankruptcy attorney in your area. The process is complex and there are many pitfalls.

Schedule C is where you list the exemption codes that you are applying to your assets listed in Schedule A/B. Schedule D is where you list your secured creditors. So if you loan is a secured loan you would list it in Schedule D and tie it to your asset in Schedule B which may affect the amount of exemption you list in Schedule C.
You may want to consult with a knowledgeable bankruptcy attorney in your area before you file your case as a DIY project.
